title: Newstart pledge complicates Labor's policy dilemma
text:
This was similar to the $12.5 billion forecast between 2019-20 and 2022-23 that the government had done by Treasury to attack the affordability of a Newstart increase.

The Treasury also forecast that a $75-a-week increase would cost $39.1 billion between 2019-20 and 2029-30, on top of the twice-yearly indexation of the base Newstart payment.

While Scott Morrison has flatly rejected calls to increase the payment, Labor has modified its policy and promised an increase that would be determined closer to the election depending on the economic and budget situation at the time.

An alternative to raising taxes to pay for the increase would be to take it out of any budget surplus.

Labor anxiety

A senior Labor source said the commitment to increase Newstart was adding anxiety to deliberations about the policy agenda, which would begin in earnest once the review into Labor's election defeat was handed down in a month from now.

He said Labor would have to offer the $75-a-week increase.

"Any amount less than what is generally accepted will make a mockery of the commitment,'' he said.

He said this would set up a conflict between moves away from a tax-and-spend agenda towards one of funding promises by growing the economy.

"You can't have it both ways,' he said.

Another source said there were few votes in lifting Newstart, no matter how worthy the cause.

The payment, currently $277 a week for a single person without children, is indexed twice a year to inflation, but has not had a real increase since 1994.

Labor's turmoil also extends to climate change, with frontbencher Joel Fitzgibbon saying on Wednesday that Labor should drop its policy to reduce emissions by 45 per cent on 2005 levels by 2030 and adopt the Coalition's 28 per cent target.

He said Labor could still best the Coalition on climate change because the government had no mechanism to reach 28 per cent, as evidenced by emissions continuing to rise under its watch.

Mr Fitzgibbon said Labor had paid too high a price over the years for climate policy.

"How any times are we going to let it kill us? Indeed, how many leaders do we want to lose to it?''

Energy Minister Angus Taylor said "we would love Labor to support our policy''.

"They are clearly recognising the error of their ways.''

But shadow climate and energy minister Mark Butler slapped down Mr Fitzgibbon's idea, saying it would be inconsistent with the Paris agreement.

"It would lead to global warming of more than 3C and, for that reason, Labor cannot support that target. That has been a consistent position of ours since we first took advice about what Tony Abbott’s target would mean for climate change,'' he said.
description: Labor's commitment to increase the Newstart allowance could require the party to retain some of its more unpopular revenue-raising policies.
